Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Zachary A. Piazza of Brown University to conduct a research project, entitled "Potential building blocks for novel materials: a joint theoretical and experimental study of highly symmetric transition-metal-centered gold clusters," during the summer of 2012 at Tsinghua Univeristy in Beijing, China. The host scientist is Professor Jun Li.

The Intellectual Merit of this research project lies in its potential to discover and understand the electronic structure of building blocks to new and useful materials while testing and aiding in the improvement of state of the art calculation methods generally useful for chemists studying many types of chemical systems. The four systems being characterized each contain one transition metal atom surrounded by 9 gold atoms. This is being done through performing theoretical relativistic quantum chemical calculations and comparing these calculations with experimental photoelectron spectroscopy data.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chemistry of gold has attracted attention due to its homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis and its wide-spread use in nanotechnology. However, little is known about  small gold compounds. Studying small gold compounds in detail can help us reveal the underlying chemical and physical reasons for the behavior of gold. The chemical bonding and electronic structure of the Au2I3- anion is being investigated by the comparison of photoelectron spectra with the most accurate theoretical calculations avilable. The Au2I3- molecule is particularly interesting to examine the relativistic effects of gold that we know are important for the catalytic behavior of hold.


We have determined that Au2I3- has a triangular structure, with the two gold atoms interacting through what is known in the literature as an "aurophilic" interaction. Aurophilicity can be described as enhanced stabilization of the Au-Au bond due to relativistic effects and occurs because of the extremely high speeds exhibited by the inner core electrons. Accurate theoretical treatment of relativistic effects thus influences how strongly the gold atoms are predicted to interact with each other, resulting in a shortened Au-Au bond distance. We have found that without including relativistic effects in the calculation of the Au2I3- system, the Au-Au bond distance will be inaccuaretely long. Furhtermore, we have benchmarked many computational inexpensive theoretical methodologies against the most accurate and expensive theoretical methodologies available today. We have found that what are known as hybrid-density-functional-theories fail at accurately describing the Au-Au bond distance, even when some relativistic effects are included. Standard density-function-theories perform much better, resulting in Au-Au bond distances similar to that predicted by the CCSD(T) method which is widely considered the most accurate quantum chemical theoretical methodology available today.
